16.text:
This painting of 'The Raising of Lazarus'  
by Joachim Wtewael

19.text: has had the most extraordinary history.

22.text:
It was discovered only a few years ago 
in a small museum outside London

26.text: at High Wycombe, the Wycombe Museum.

29.text:
Now, this is actually mainly a museum of 
furniture and decorative arts

33.text:
and they think they were given it possibly in 1932, 
just possibly earlier than that.

40.text:
But judging by its state they can’t ever 
have been able to display it.

44.text: It was completely unexhibitable, it had no frame

47.text:
and it was covered by an incredibly thick, 
very discoloured brown varnish.

52.text:
I think actually it’s the heaviest, darkest varnish 
I’ve ever had to remove from a painting.

57.text:
But as well as that it was in poor condition, there 
were visible damages, it had had holes knocked into it

64.text: and a large tear in the area of the old man

68.text: where something perhaps with a sharp corner had knocked against it.

72.text: But the first thing that we do when we’re proposing to treat a painting is find out as much as possible about its

79.text:
condition and we do this using techniques like 
x-radiography and infrared reflectography.

86.text:
When the results came back from the x-radiographs we 
were actually very worried because it showed us that

94.text:
underneath all the thick brown varnish we 
had a very, very damaged painting,

100.text: one that had possibly been folded or perhaps rolled and then the roll of canvas was crushed.

106.text: And the x-ray told us that a great deal of paint had fallen off and that the restoration,

112.text: which was almost certainly 19th century, was covering a lot of damage.

118.text: However, we could also see that large parts of the picture weren’t in such a bad state,

124.text: that the lower part was generally not too bad and that with one exception all the heads were good,

130.text: and again with one exception the hands, which are such an important part of Joachim Wtewael’s work,

135.text:
were in perfectly good condition.
So the cleaning started

140.text: and this was a very, very slow process,

144.text: gradually dissolving off the thick yellow varnish but also large amounts of repainting that had been put on,

152.text: fortunately in the 19th century, which meant that it wasn’t terribly hard and difficult to get off,

159.text: And gradually, gradually as the overpaint came off and all the varnish,

165.text: Joachim Wtewael’s original paint was revealed,

168.text: a painting in very, very damaged condition,

171.text: there’s no denying that, but also with passages of tremendous quality.

176.text: The restoration process was slow and laborious. The first thing I had to do was to fill all the missing areas

185.text: because you can’t just retouch on the bare canvas where all the paint has crumbled away and I had to fill it

191.text: and then put in the base colour that Joachim Wtewael had used; the priming, we call it, and in this case it

199.text: was this rather cool, pale grey. And we find this in all of Wtewael’s paintings

205.text: that have been examined by scientists,

207.text: that he liked to paint on this grey surface. And indeed he actually makes it part of his painting technique,

214.text: in some of the lighter parts of the painting the grey is very clearly visible and so it was important that I

221.text: started, even in the smallest of losses, with exactly the same base colour that he used.

227.text: So it took me some time to mix it to get it absolutely right and then months –

232.text: it was much the most tedious part

234.text: of the work – with the painting on a table, gradually filling in the holes and giving myself a good starting

241.text: point for working with the colour. The colour part, it was challenging because of the enormous number of losses

249.text: and the places where they were but it’s actually been immensely rewarding, I would almost say fun,

257.text: because it’s been incredible to see how the painting has slowly come back together again.

263.text: It’s not our intention in restoring paintings to take them right back to what we think they were like

268.text: when the artist first completed them. After all, we can’t possibly know, but it’s to find a level that I could apply

275.text: to the whole of the painting, leaving it looking like an old and damaged painting because that is what it is,

282.text: but at the same time allowing it to function as a picture that people can enjoy.
